(i)  The fiscal year (FY) of the Government ends on 30 September. FY before a

This report was prepared by H. Kawada, Senior Programs Officer, Pacific Department.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the Federated States of Micronesia (FSM) has requested the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  provide  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  the  preparation  and 
formulation of an Omnibus Infrastructure Development Project (OIDP) that will address the 
specific and immediate needs for rehabilitation and improvement of the infrastructure in each of 
its four States: Pohnpei, Chuuk, Yap, and Kosrae. 1 The ADB Country Programming Mission, 
during its 27 May to 6 June 2002 visit to the FSM, conducted a fact-finding exercise and 
reached an understanding with the National Government on a broad framework of the TA. 
Another ADB mission was fielded from 21 October to 1 November 2002 to sharpen the focus 
and components of the TA. The mission also visited the project areas, carried out an initial 
poverty and social assessment (Appendix 1), and discussed economic and social development 
issues  as  well  as  project-specific  issues  with  the  officials  of  the  national  and  four  state 
governments as well as the utility corporations. This report is based on the understanding 
reached with the Government on the goals, purpose, scope, implementation arrangements, 
costs, financing arrangements, and terms of reference, and the mission’s observations in the 
field. A TA framework is presented in Appendix 2. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Since the FSM’s independence in 1987, infrastructure development has received special 
emphasis in its economic strategy under the Compact of Free Association (CFA) with the United 
States  (US)  Government.  Although  much  has  been  accomplished,  infrastructure  remains 
deficient in many respects. In a recent exercise conducted by the FSM National Government for 
preparation  of  the  Infrastructure  Development  Plan  (IDP),2  the  total  cost  of  the  capital 
investment  necessary  over  the  next  15  years  was  estimated  at  nearly  $2  billion.  Recent 
developments have underscored the urgency of measures to address gaps in infrastructure. 
The recent cholera outbreak in Pohnpei has helped focus Government attention on the fact that 
inadequate  water  and  waste  management  infrastructure  and  facilities  can  threaten  the 
environment and impede economic development. 
 
3.  The  National  Government  is  in  the  final  stages  of  negotiating  with  the  US  for  an 
extension of the CFA for another 20 years from FY2003 to FY2023. The indications are that the 
allocation for the infrastructure sector under the proposed CFA extension would be significantly 
below the needs of the sector. The National Government is therefore looking at alternate 
sources to supplement the funds from the US for its infrastructure development program. 
 
4.  ADB  has  thus  far  financed  only  one  infrastructure  loan3  in  the  water  supply  and 
sanitation sector, covering three of the four states. This project was closed in October 2002. In 
addition,  ADB  has  financed  two  other  projects  and  one  program,4  all  designed  to  aid  in 
improving the social infrastructure and help in public sector reform. The conditions and needs 
for rehabilitation and improvement of physical infrastructure vary from state to state.

5.  Pohnpei State. As in the other states, urban infrastructure has been overloaded owing 
to  the  migration  of  outer  islanders  to  urban  centers  for  education  facilities,  employment 
opportunities, business activities, and other day-to-day needs. The existing Kolonia Sewerage 
System, built in the mid-1970s, is currently overloaded and has reached its life expectancy of 25 
years. The main urban center of the State of Pohnpei has seen a significant growth in its 
population and in business and commercial activities. The system originally operated by the 
then Department of Public Works of the Pohnpei State Government was transferred to the 
Pohnpei Utilities Corporation (PUC) in 1993 for operation, maintenance, and management. No 
expansion has been undertaken other than the addition of connections to new customers. Due 
to overutilization, PUC has been experiencing overflow at the sewage treatment plant and lift 
pump  stations.  This  has  created  serious  environmental  problems  for  the  ever-expanding 
residential households and adjacent communities, and for the municipal areas of nearby Nett 
and Sokehs Islands. To support the growing need for safe water and to provide it to the people 
of Pohnpei, the Nanpil Water Reservoir needs expansion. The average flow of the Nanpil River 
is approximately 6.0 million gallons per day (mgd), whereas PUC receives only 2.5 mgd on 
average. It is required to rehabilitate and expand the Nanpil Water Reservoir to meet rising 
water demand during drought periods. 
 
6.  Chuuk State. A review of infrastructure priorities has revealed that urgent assistance is 
required to improve the power sector. There is not enough power generation capacity to meet 
the existing demand for electricity, and the distribution system is in urgent need of rehabilitation 
and upgrading. Even the water supply of Weno Island, which depends mainly on groundwater 
wells, is being hampered due to intermittent power supply. The shortage of the power supply in 
Chuuk is apparently hindering the economic activities of the private sector, including the tourism 
industry, and removing this bottleneck is an urgent need of Chuuk State. 
 
7.  The state-owned Chuuk Public Utilities Corporation (CPUC), which operates the power 
system, is considering the introduction of a trash incinerator power plant rather than diesel 
power plants, partly to address issues of solid waste management. There is no solid waste 
management system in the state, and garbage builds up in public places such as the harbor and 
seafront  without  any  environmental  protective  measures.  Continuation  of  this  practice  will 
contaminate the lagoon, which is the heart of marine and tourism resources of the state. 
 
8.  CPUC operations in electricity are not yet profitable, for example incurring more than a 
$2 million operating loss in FY2000. CPUC received an annual fuel subsidy from the state 
government of more than $1 million for 1998–2000. The revenue collection rate is relatively low 
at 80%, and a significant amount of unpaid bills exists. This is partly due to the fact that many 
electricity customers are not yet metered. Strengthening the capacity of CPUC in terms of cost 
recovery is urgently needed to increase its income stream. 
 
9.  Kosrae State. This state consists of a single island and a population of about 8,000, or 
about 1,100 households. Kosrae Utility Authority is responsible for the management, operation, 
and maintenance of the power system. Kosrae was unable to participate in the previous ADB 
infrastructure project due to difficulty in legislating the existing ADB requirements. The Fact-
Finding Mission was informed that the state is now ready to undertake the necessary legislative 
requirements. The quality of water delivered from the water supply system is not satisfactory, 
mainly due to either a lack or malfunctioning of chlorination and filtration plants. There is a need 
to reorganize the water system on the island and to rehabilitate the water treatment plants and 
distribution systems in order to supply reliable and safe drinking water. Assistance has also

3 
been requested for wastewater treatment and management of the existing system covering 
oxidation pond, small borehole sewer, and septic tank with leach field. 
 
10.  Yap State. With its population of about 12,000, Yap has been the most efficient in 
managing infrastructure needs. The power, water, and wastewater systems on the main island 
are currently managed by the Yap State Public Service Corporation. The water supply system in 
the  main  island  benefited  from  the  recent  Water  Supply  and  Sanitation  Project  through 
increased wells and water tanks as well as extension of water pipes. However, some areas 
such as Maap and Rumung still need the development of a water supply system to increase 
access to safe water, since they are currently depending on small-scale village water supply 
systems that use streams, springs, or seeps as water sources, and sometimes these sources 
dry out with the low level of rainfall. 
 
11.  Institutional Capacity. The main service deliverers of the power, water supply, and 
wastewater management subsectors have been state-owned utility corporations. This approach 
has generally been considered appropriate to date. However, the institutional capacities of utility 
corporations vary state by state; some require substantial institutional strengthening in terms of, 
among  others,  technical  and  financial  planning,  facility  maintenance,  billing  and  revenue 
collection, human resource training and supervision, and strategic decision making. It would be 
worthwhile  to  consider  whether  private  sector  participation  could  benefit  the  institutional 
strengthening of these corporations. ADB’s sector policy is to continue to support private sector-
led  initiatives  and  provide  the  necessary  infrastructure  to  support  such  activities.  ADB’s 
operational strategy for the FSM is broadly consistent with this approach. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
12.  The principal objective of the TA is to assist the Government in assessing the feasibility 
of the OIDP for possible ADB financing. The TA will carry out a feasibility study for a project to 
improve the water supply and sanitation infrastructure mainly in Pohnpei, Kosrae, and Yap 
states, and the power sector infrastructure in Chuuk state. This exercise will include a study of 
the deteriorating infrastructure, evaluating the reasons for the high level of deterioration, and 
alternative solutions. The TA will also review the areas covered by the recent infrastructure 
project and incorporate the lessons learned. The project will consider direct private sector 
participation or any other transformation of state utility corporations where possible. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The TA will consist of preparation, formulation, and design of a proposed OIDP for the 
FSM. It will review the list of infrastructure projects identified under the FSM IDP; conduct a 
study of the status of the existing infrastructure, along with the impact of the recent water 
project; and clearly determine the factors causing the significant deterioration. The adequacy of 
operation and maintenance funding and administrative arrangements will also be assessed. As 
part of the TA, the consultants will also prepare an assessment of the likely poverty and social 
impact of each subproject, including an analysis of the distribution of project effects and poverty 
impact ratio, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects. The 
project paper will be prepared based on the findings of the study, with balanced attention to the 
urgent infrastructure needs as well as the policy framework and management systems to ensure 
adequate operation and maintenance efforts in each of the four states.

4 
14.  In the feasibility studies, the TA will also carry out, among others (i) sector/subsector 
analyses; (ii) an institutional analysis of executing agencies and implementation agencies, with 
a recommendation for possible transformation of state utility corporations; (iii) an environmental 
assessment; (iv) analyses on poverty and social issues and preparation of a summary poverty 
reduction and social strategy (SPRSS) paper, (v) preparation of a participatory strategy; (vi) an 
analysis of the sustainability of the proposed project, and recommendations and suggestions on 
the specific policies and strategies to ensure the cost recovery, tariff structure, maintenance of 
the infrastructure, and sustainability of the infrastructure services; (vii) economic internal rate of 
return  and  financial  internal  rate  of  return  analyses  for  each  subproject;  and  (viii) 
recommendation on project benefit monitoring and evaluation as well as preparation of  baseline 
data for project benefit monitoring. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $814,000 equivalent, of which $563,000 is the 
foreign  exchange  cost  and  $251,000  equivalent  is  the  local  currency  cost.  The  National 
Government has requested ADB to finance $650,000 equivalent, covering the entire foreign 
exchange cost and $87,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed by 
ADB on a grant basis from the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The 
Government will finance the balance of the local currency cost equivalent to $164,000. Details 
of the cost estimates and financing plan are provided in Appendix 3. The Government has been 
informed that provision of this TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 6 months beginning in March 2003 by a 
team of consultants to be engaged from a firm, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants using the simplified technical proposal and the quality and cost-based selection 
method  along  with  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  engagement  of  domestic 
consultants. The TA will require about 20 person-months of international consulting services in 
the fields of power generation and distribution; water supply and sanitation; economic, financial, 
and  institutional  analysis;  and  environmental  and  social  analysis.  In  addition,  domestic 
consultants will be engaged to assist the foreign consultant for 5 person-months. The terms of 
reference for the consultants are in Appendix 4. The target completion date of the TA is 15 
September 2003. 
 
17.  The  Executing  Agency  for  the  TA  will  be  the  Department  of  Transportation, 
Communications, and Infrastructure (DTCI). To facilitate the TA, a TA steering committee, 
chaired by the secretary of DTCI and comprising senior officials of DTCI and the departments of 
Economic Affairs, Finance and Administration, Health, and Education will be responsible for 
direction and policy formulation under the TA, and for ensuring effective liaison, data collation, 
and discussion among the Government, the private sector, and the consultants. The respective 
state governments will be consulted by the TA steering committee and DTCI. The secretary of 
DTCI will be the focal point for the consultant team and will provide coordination among the 
National  Government,  state  governments,  agencies,  nongovernment  organizations,  and 
consultants. DTCI counterpart staff will assist the consultants and become fully familiarized with 
the TA details. 
 
18.  The consultants will prepare and submit to the National Government, state governments, 
ADB, and the Executing Agency the following reports: (i) an inception report confirming the 
team’s work program; (ii) brief monthly summary reports summarizing inputs and results; (iii)

5 
reports  on  the  design  and  feasibility  of  infrastructure  subprojects;  and  (iv)  a  final  report 
incorporating  the  comments  of  ADB,  the  National  Government,  and  the  concerned 
implementation agencies. The TA will be reviewed jointly by ADB, the National Government, 
and the consultants upon presentation of the inception report and at the conclusion of the TA. 
The final report, incorporating comments of the Government and ADB, will be submitted within 1 
month of receipt of the comments. The consultants will adopt a team approach to carry out their 
tasks and a process approach to incorporate adjustments, if any, as the work proceeds and new 
findings come out. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $650,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Federated States of Micronesia for preparing the Omnibus Infrastructure 
Development Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 4  11 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Objectives, Scope, and Approach 
1.  The objective of the consulting services is to prepare a feasibility study for the Omnibus 
Infrastructure Development Project in the Federated States of Micronesia (FSM) that complies 
with  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)’s  requirements  for  feasibility  documentation.  The 
consultants will prepare comprehensive information on all aspects of the proposed project, 
including  technical,  financial,  economic,  social,  environmental,  poverty,  and  infrastructure- 
related policy matters. The consultants will visit project sites; consult a cross-section of project 
beneficiaries; identify project implementation capacities and arrangements; estimate project 
costs and explore cofinancing arrangements; and systematically assess the project and the 
sector—including  developing  a  project  framework,  analyzing  constraints,  opportunities,  and 
demands, and doing social surveys and an environmental evaluation. 
 
2.  The  consultants  will  carry  out  the  assignment  in  an  inclusive  manner  meaningfully 
consulting with national and state government officials, state utility corporations, utility users, 
national planners, affected communities, and involved external agencies. The consultants will 
focus on identifying and alleviating the immediate constraints that FSM infrastructure poses to 
poverty reduction and socioeconomic development without neglecting the long-term economic 
rationale of the utility services. The consultants will take note of all existing assessments and 
reports available on the sectors. 
 
3.  Although the specific activities and outputs of individual consultant are provided below, 
the consultants will adopt a team approach to carry out analyses and produce outputs under the 
strong leadership and coordination role of the team leader. The consultants should also adopt a 
process approach to incorporate adjustments in assignments, if required, as the work proceeds 
and new findings come out. 
 
B.  Water Supply Specialist/Team Leader (5 person-months) 
4.  The consultant’s assignment will include, but not be limited to, the following:  
 
(i)  Examine  the  National  and  state  governments’  objectives  for  infrastructure 
development and review the Infrastructure Development Plan (IDP) prepared by 
the FSM National Government, including the prioritized infrastructure projects. 
 
(ii)  Carry out a condition survey of the existing infrastructure with an emphasis on 
the water supply and sanitation sector in the FSM in terms of physical condition, 
operating efficiency, technological appropriateness, useful life remaining, and 
operation and maintenance requirements. 
 
(iii)  Based on the assessment, identify and formulate infrastructure subprojects in 
each state. 
 
(iv)  Review the materials and equipment lists and estimates, unit prices, and cost 
estimates for each subproject. Cost estimates should include allowances and 
contingencies normally associated with such projects in the FSM and for ADB 
projects,  including  engineering  fees,  physical  contingency,  price  contingency,

inflation  from  2003  base  prices  through  procurement/bidding,  interest  during 
construction, administration fees, etc. 
 
(v)  Define in detail all aspects of the project in accordance with ADB’s business 
processes requirements and in relation to ADB’s Pacific Strategy. In consultation 
with ADB, and in collaboration with other consultant team members, prepare a 
comprehensive  feasibility  study  in  the  form  of  ADB’s  Report  and 
Recommendation  to  the  President  for  a  project  loan,  with  detailed  project 
designs,  including  detailed  analysis  on  the  criteria  for  selection  of  the 
subprojects, project framework, problems, constraints, overall sector analysis, 
other agencies’ assistance in the sectors, cost estimates and financing plan, 
contract  packages  (civil  works,  equipment,  etc.),  implementation  schedules, 
financial  performance  and  projections  of  state  governments  and  state  utility 
corporations,  environmental  analysis,  poverty  reduction  and  social  strategy, 
terms of reference for consulting services, and a framework for benefit monitoring 
and evaluation and its database. 
 
(vi)  Perform other tasks as necessary upon request of the assigned project officer of 
ADB. 
 
C.  Power Sector Specialist (3 person-months) 
 
5.  The consultant’s assignment will include, but not be limited to, the following:  
 
(i)  Examine  the  National  and  state  governments’  objectives  for  infrastructure 
development and review the IDP, including the prioritized infrastructure projects. 
 
(ii)  Carry out a condition survey of the existing infrastructure with an emphasis on 
the power sector in Chuuk in terms of physical condition, operating efficiency, 
technological  appropriateness,  useful  life  remaining  and  operation  and 
maintenance requirements. 
 
(iii)  Based on the assessment, with the close collaboration of other consultants, 
identify  and  formulate  an  infrastructure  subproject  in  Chuuk  State,  including 
detailed  cost  estimates,  contract  packages  (civil  works,  equipment  etc.), 
implementation  schedule,  financial  performance  and  projections  of  state 
governments  and  state  utility  corporations,  environmental  analysis,  poverty

framework for benefit monitoring and evaluation and its database. 
 
(iv)  Perform other tasks as necessary upon request of the assigned project officer of 
ADB or the team leader.

(i)  In accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects,  
Handbook for the Economic Analysis of Water Supply Projects; and Economic 
Analysis of Environmental Impacts: A Workbook: Criteria for Subsidies, conduct 
the  project  economic  analysis  in  form  and  substance  agreeable  to  ADB,

covering, inter alia, demand forecast, least economic cost analysis, economic

F.  Poverty and Social Development Specialist (4 person-months) 
 
8.  The consultant’s assignment will include, but not be limited to, the following: 
 
(i)  Prepare socioeconomic and poverty profiles for the project area. Data will be 
collected  from  statistical  records  through  field  surveys  and  key  informant 
interviews and participatory community appraisal techniques. The information 
should include population, income levels, occupations, unemployment, education 
levels, health conditions, and other relevant socioeconomic data. Data should be 
disaggregated  by  gender.  The  data  and  profiles  should  be  sufficiently 
comprehensive to serve as the baseline for socioeconomic benefit monitoring. 
Collect socioeconomic data about the priority areas and assess the major social 
issues and constraints. Evaluate the socioeconomic conditions and the ability of 
the local population to pay for power, water supply, and sanitation services. 
Conduct  consensus-building  exercises  for  the  technology  options,  project 
locations, willingness to pay, and their role in the successful implementation of 
the project. 
 
(ii)  Based on the initial poverty and social assessment, conduct a full poverty and 
social assessment in accordance with ADB’s Handbook on Poverty and Social 
Analysis  and  Handbook  for  Incorporation  of  Social  Dimensions  in  Projects. 
Assess  how  the  proposed  project  may  help  improve  people’s  livelihoods.  In 
collaboration with other member of consultant team, the analysis will estimate (a) 
the number of project beneficiaries by area, occupation, and income level; and 
(b) the number of adversely affected people by type of impact. Specify how the 
project will improve benefits for the local people by income group. Recommend 
measures to enhance benefits and minimize adverse impacts, particularly for the 
poor. The cost of such measures and the means for implementing them will be 
clearly proposed. Review and recommend the appropriate poverty classification 
for the project based on ADB’s loan classification system.   
 
(iii)  Perform other tasks as necessary upon request of the assigned project officer of 
ADB or the team leader. 
 
G.  Domestic Consultants (5 person-months) 
 
9.  Domestic consulting will be provided to assist the international consulting team mainly in 
the areas of environmental, poverty, and social analysis, as well as economic, financial, and 
institutional analysis.

services (contained in the consultants’ proposal) that are required to fulfill the 
terms of reference.
